title: Integrate with SAP Solution Manager
content:
This topic provides complete information for integrating SMAX with SAP Solution Manager. This integration can implement bidirectional Incident Case Exchange through seamless integration between SMAX and an external Service Provider that uses SAP Solution Manager as a ticketing tool.  

Benefits of integrating

The integration of SMAX with SAP Solution Manager adds the following capabilities to your current deployment:: 

  • Integrate external service providers seamlessly and remove inefficiencies due to disconnected Service Desks with the following benefits: 
    • Clear information exchange and E2E view about incidents and incident status 
    • Consistent information
    • Coherent tracking and reporting of incidents 
    • Close collaboration when working on incidents 
    • Improved insight into interrelationships between SAP solutions and other IT components  
  • Bring new value to IT and the business due to increased ability to proactively reduce risk of disruptions, by 
    • Uniquely fast resolution of incidents  
      • increased availability of SAP solutions and critical business processes  
      • reduced costs 
    • Higher productivity in IT operations 
      • avoiding duplication of work 
      • saving time of IT persons  
    • Improved IT service quality 
      • faster resolution of disruptive events 
      • increased IT customer satisfaction 

This document describes a use case that's about exchanging Incident details between SMAX and SAP Solution Manager, and provides step-by-step guidance for setting up similar custom integrations. The documented use case is an example of how you can implement such an integration with OpenText products, without the need for modifications in SAP Solution Manager.

Use case - Incident Exchange between SMAX and SAP Solution Manager

The following diagram illustrates the integration architecture.

The following table gives the component details:

Component Description
SMAX SMAX is a Service Management system to handle and support users with their IT processes. In this integration, SMAX is acting as an end user system, forwarding Incidents to SAP Solution Manager.
Operations Orchestration (OO) OO is middleware between SMAX and SAP Solution Manager. OO is receiving the data from Service Management, transforming it for SAP, and then using the SAP REST API to open and update SAP Incidents.
SAP Solution Manager SAP Solution Manager is an endpoint to handle SAP related IT issues and support the local IT using SMAX in their support processes.

You can implement the following use case with the details provided in this document.

SMAX:

  1. An end user raises a support request through the service portal in Service Management.
  2. The system creates an incident from the support request and automatically classifies, assigns, and sends the incident to SAP Solution Manager. 
  3. The system forwards any new information in the SMAX ticket to SAP.
  4. The system refreshes the ticket in Service Management with the latest details from SAP Solution Manager.
  5. The agent is able to access the Incident in SAP Solution Manager by using a URL.
  6. The agent closes the incident manually in Service Management, according to the details from SAP Solution Manager.
  7. The system informs the end user, who can then accept or reject the solution proposal.

SAP Solution Manager

  1. SAP Solution Manager receives the Incident details and then creates a new ticket.
  2. The SAP agent works on the ticket, and the integration pulls recent conversations and actual status into Service Management.
  3. If the SAP agent documents a solution proposal, the SMAX ticket automatically enters the Validation phase.

The following steps show this example use case.

Step 1: End user asks for SAP Payroll support

In this sample use case, end users can open a support request to ask for help in the event of issues with certain applications.

Follow the steps below taken by Jason, an employee who is working on a regular basis in the SAP Payroll application to manage employee payrolls. While Jason is using the company's standard portal to ask for IT support, some IT services are outsourced to external service providers, so is the company's SAP system. However, the seamless integration from the Portal through the Incident Management system to the external provider makes this internal detail transparent to Jason and other application end users.

Portal access

Jason logs in to the Self -Service Portal where Jason has access to a variety of self-service support features such as catalog, knowledge, and subscription management for the applications that Jason uses every day.

Submitting the Enhancement Request with help of the Virtual Agent

Jason proceeds to get help from the Portal Virtual Agent, requesting support for accessing the SAP Payroll application. The Virtual Agent assists by providing Jason with a support request form.

The virtual agent is proposing the best offering to help Jason.

 Jason selects SAP Payroll support, and the system routes the request directly to the correct internal and external groups to get help as fast as possible.

After submitting the request, Jason can monitor the status directly in the portal.

Step 2: The system is handling the incident in the backend

After Jason has submitted the request, the system automatically creates a linked Incident to correctly track this issue and assigns it to the correct teams supporting this application. All details are copied from the original support request into the Incident.

Since the SAP Payroll application is maintained by an external service provider, the Incident in Service Management is forwarded to the Service Provider's ticketing system.

From that point, the second-level and third-level support teams can work together via their standard ticketing system and share all technical details with each other to solve Jason's issues.

The incident is automatically assigned to the second-level team and the external service provider by using the SAP Support (Europe) expert group. The system also documents the reference ID of the external ticketing system.

The second-level team can now easily collaborate with the external service provider, by simply entering new information into the SMAX incident. The system forwards the details to the service provider automatically and monitors any updates to the ticket in SAP Solution Manager.

By clicking the URL, the SMAX user can see the overall history of the ticket directly in SAP.

(Use SAP demo user “wangca” with password Solman72 to view the record in SAP, take ownership, and modify it.)

On the SAP side, the engineer can see the updates from SMAX and can further add details to the ticket.

(Use SAP user “wangca” with password Solman72 and the link from the External Reference section in the General tab.)

Whereas the engineer in Service Management can see the updates or questions from the external service provider.

Note: To get the updates from SAP quickly, use the Get Updates from SAP button, and it will take about one minute to see the latest updates from SAP in Service Management. You need to refresh the screen to see the latest updates. Without using the button it takes around one hour to see the updates reflected in Service Management.

If the SAP engineer is proposing a solution, the ticket in Service Management is updated with the solution details, the Incident is moved to the Review phase, and the end user is informed about the proposed solution.

Note: Remember to use the Get Updates from SAP button to see the results quickly in Service Management.

Step 3: End user confirms or rejects the solution

Back in the self-service portal. Since the Incident was updated with a solution proposal, the end user's support request is moved to the Validation phase, waiting for confirmation from the end user.

Step 4: Incident is closed

If the solution was accepted, the support request is closed, and the related Incident can be closed.

By clicking Close, the Incident is closed, and an update is sent to SAP Solution Manager.

This informs the external Service Provider that the ticket was closed in Service Management.

Set up the integration

To achieve the example use case, perform the following steps to set up the integration:

  1. Meet prerequisites
  2. Configure SAP
  3. Configure OO
  4. Configure SMAX

Meet prerequisites

You must meet the following prerequisites to configure the documented integration in your environment.

OpenText:

  • SMAX
    • On-Premises Bridge
  • Operations Orchestration (OO)
    • Minimum required version: 10.80
    • Content Packs
      • OO Base content 1.12.3

SAP:

The documented integration was tested against the following SAP landscape:

  • SAP Solution Manager 7.2 (ST SP07, ST-OST 200 SP02)
  • SAP S/4HANA 1610 FP00 as a managed system
  • SAP HANA 2.0

This integration requires the SAP Fiori apps with the API components and services listed in the following table.

Fiori component Details Used for
Create Incident Service Type: OData Service

Service Name: AI_CRM_GW_CREATE_INCIDENT_SRV

Details

 To create Incidents in SAP
My Incident Service Type: OData Service

Service Name: AI_CRM_GW_MYMESSAGE_SRV

Details

 To send comments from SMAX to SAP
Resolve and Dispatch Incidents Service Type: OData Service

Service Name: AI_CRM_GW_RES_DISP_INCIDENTS_SRV

Details

 To search and get the latest SAP updates

SAP demo system used for testing the integration: https://support.sap.com/en/alm/demo-systems/internet-demo-system.html

Configure SAP

  1. Ensure the required Services listed in the prerequisites section are published and accessible.
  2. Create an integration user with the correct access rights to use the "ODATA services" mentioned above to create, search and update Incidents in SAP Solution Manager.

Configure OO

This section describes the steps to prepare OO:

  1. Install OO.
  2. Disable CSRF
  3. Deploy the content packs
  4. Configure the OO flows
  5. Modify the OO flows (optional and not documented below)

Step 1: Install OO

We recommend that you install OO 10.80 or later. We haven't tested the provided OO flows on earlier versions of OO. 

  • Install the OO Central component. You need it to run the provided flows.
  • If you want to modify the provided flows, install the OO Studio component. 

For details, refer to the OO installation documentation. For example: Install OO

Step 2: Disable CSRF protection

Since SMAX currently only supports Basic Authentication for REST-based communications, you must disable CSFR protection in OO.

For details, refer to the OO documentation. For example: Disable CSFR

Step 3: Deploy the content packs

Deploy the OO Base content pack and the SMAX content pack in OO. Note that existing content packs will be overwritten with their new version. 

  1. Deploy the OO Base content pack (minimum version 1.12.3).
    1. Download the OO base content pack from the ITOM Marketplace.
    2. Upload the base content pack into your OO system.
  2. Deploy the Service Management Automation content pack.
    1. Download the OO Service Management Content content pack from the ITOM Marketplace.
    2. Go to your OO Web client.
    3. Navigate to Content Management > Content Pack and add the Service Management Automation content pack. Ensure that you have successfully imported the content pack without errors.

    The SAP Solution Manager integration requires the following OO flows.

    Flow Description
    Connect to SMAX Establishes a connection to Service Management,to get the LW-SSO cookie used in subsequent steps of the flow.

    Used as a subflow in the following flows:

    • Create Incident in SAP
    • Pull Updates from SAP
    • Update Incident in SAP
    Create Incident in SAP Creates an Incident in SAP.
    Pull Updates from SAP Pulls the updates from SAP based on the last PULL timestamp, and also filters out all updates made from SMAX in SAP since the last pull.
    Update Incident in SAP Sends the latest comments to SAP.
    Update Incident in Service Management

    Updates the Incident in Service Management with the latest details from SAP.

    Used as a subflow in the following flows:

    • Create Incident in SAP
    • Pull Updates from SAP
    • Update Incident in SAP

     For more technical details about the provided OO flows, see Technical details about the OO flows.

Step 4: Configure the OO flows

  1. Configure a system account to allow OO to connect to SAP and Service Management.
    1. Click Content Management > Configuration Items.
    2. Go to the Content Management > Configuration Items > Configuration/System Properties/Integrations/Micro Focus/Service Management Automation X/ SAP Solution Manager folder and configure the following System Accounts.
      Parameter Default value Comment
      SAP Credentials  <none> This is the SAP user to open and update Incidents.
      SMAX Credentials <none> This is the SMAX user configured in the External System (see step 3 in the Configure SMAX section) to update the Incidents in Service Management.
      Folder Proxy:

      Proxy User

      		 <none> If a proxy is required, set the user name/password here.

       Example:

  2. Configure System Properties. To do so, configure the required parameters of the OO flows, such as URLs, user names, and passwords.
    1. Click Content Management > Configuration Items.
    2. Go to the Content Management > Configuration Items > Configuration/System Properties/Integrations/Micro Focus/Service Management Automation X/ folder and then go to the following subfolders:
      • SAP Solution Manager
      • SMAX

      Configure the system properties described in the following table.

      Parameter Default Value Comment
      SAPBaseURL <none> This is the URL to your SAP Solution Manager system.
      SAPCreateURI /opu/odata/sap/AI_CRM_GW_CREATE_INCIDENT_SRV This is the URI to the fiori app to create Incidents.
      SAPDateFormat dd.mm.yyyy This is the date format of the SAP remote agent to ensure we can filter the latest updates properly.
      SAPGetTicketURI /opu/odata/sap/AI_CRM_GW_RES_DISP_INCIDENTS_SRV This is the URI to the fiori app to search for an Incident to get the latest data.
      SAPRemoteAgentEmail <none> This is the email address of the SAP Remote agent, to filter out the comments this user created (typically the updates provided by SMAX).
      SAPTicketURI /bc/ui5_ui5/ui2/ushell/shells/abap/FioriLaunchpad.html#Action-SMResolveDispatchIncidents&/IncidentSet This is URI to launch the Incident in the SAP UI.
      SAPUpdateURI /opu/odata/sap/AI_CRM_GW_MYMESSAGE_SRV This is the URI to the fiori app to send comments from SMAX into the SAP history.
      SAPAcceptLanguage en The language in which SAP will return some enum and status values.
      SMAXBaseURL <none> This is the Base URL to your SMAX instance.
      SMAXLoginURI /auth/authentication-endpoint/authenticate/login This is the SMAX login URI appended to the SMAX Base URL.
      ProxyHost <none> This is the proxy host.
      ProxyPort <none> This is the proxy port.

       Example:

Configure SMAX

The following is a summary of the steps to configure the integration shown above in Service Management: 

  1. Set up an On-Premise Bridge (OPB) agent. 
  2. Add a REST execution endpoint for invoking OO APIs. 
  3. Set up an External System.
  4. Configure the Incident Workflow. 
  5. Configure the External Groups.
  6. Create a Service Offering (optional).
  7. Verify the execution.  

Step 1: Set up an On-Premises Bridge agent

Before you begin, you may want to read general background details for setting up integrations in REST Execution, which includes further information on setting up the On-Premise Bridge, which is used to enable REST integration communications from SMAX to external systems.

Note:  Be sure to import the SMAX CA certificate and OO CA certificate into the On-Premises Bridge so that OPB can establish a connection to SMAX and OO. For detailed instructions, see How to import certificates into OPB.

Step 2: Add a REST execution endpoint for invoking OO REST APIs 

Once you have an On-Premise Bridge (OPB) endpoint agent available, the next step is to add an endpoint that will be used to call our REST APIs into the OO system: 

Note The ability to run OO flows via REST requires your OO Server to be enabled to accept Basic Authentication API invocations. To allows this, you must turn off OO CSRF Protection. See the OO documentation for more details.

  1. In the Administration Menu, navigate to Integration Management  > ENDPOINTS.
  2. Press the +Add button to create a new endpoint: 
    1. Select Rest Executor as the Endpoint type. 
    2. Provide a name (such as REST).
    3. Specify the OPB agent that will enable the endpoint.
  3. Configure the endpoint once you have created it:
    1. Enter the REST URL location from OO, such as http://<oo server>/oo/rest/v2.
    2. Select the credentials entered in the On-Premises Bridge to connect to the OO Server.

For more details about endpoints, see On-Premises Bridge Agents and Endpoints. 

Step 3: Set up an external system

To activate the Case Exchange API in Service Management, you must set up an External System. To set up an External System, perform the following steps:

  1. In the Administration Menu, navigate to Integration Management > EXTERNAL SYSTEMS.
  2. Click New to create a new external system:
    1. Provide a System id and a short description.
    2. Specify the Authorized user. Note: This user is used in OO to update the SMAX incidents with the latest information from SAP Solution Manager. Ensure that this user is entitled to update Incidents.
  3. Edit the External System once you have created it, and reference the endpoint created in Step 3.
  4. Select the Cancel option at the bottom of the screen. This is currently used as a workaround because the Create option isn't fully supported.

For more details about External Systems, see External systems.

Step 4: Configure the assignment group

To ensure SMAX is able to send tickets to SAP Solution Manager, once the Incident is assigned to a group, the group needs to be linked to the External System created in "Step 3: Set up an external system".

To do so, perform the following steps:

  1. In the Administration Menu, navigate to MASTER DATA > PEOPLE > GROUPS.
  2.  Select your group (or create a new one), and link it with an External System.

For more details about Groups and External Systems, see Groups.

Step 5: Configure the Incident workflow

In this step, configure the Incident workflow so that the system triggers the case exchange with SAP Solution Manager. This step includes the following tasks:

  1. Add new fields
  2. Create a custom action
  3. Create rules
See the following for the task details.
Add new fields

To implement this integration, you need the following additional attributes for the Incident record type.

Attribute Type Description
Name: LastPull

Flags: Readonly

 Date_Time Stores the timestamp of the last pull activity from SAP
Name: Output

Flags: Readonly

 Medium_Text Stores the output of the last processed OO Flow
Name: SAPGUIID

Flags: Readonly

 Medium_Text Stored the unique SAP GUIID which is required to update records in SAP.

 To add these attributes, navigate to STUDIO, select Incident, and create the new Fields as described above.

Create a custom action

You need to create a custom action to “pull” the latest updates from SAP on demand. Although the system is pulling automatically on an hourly basis, Incident Analyst may want to pull more frequently.

Navigate to STUDIO, select Custom Action and create a new Custom Action as shown in the example below.

Note: Ensure the Enable workflow checkbox is selected.

The custom action is then triggering a rule documented in the rule section. 

Create rules

Now, click Processes and Rules to configure the required logic to send incidents to SAP Solution Manager.

1 – Create Incident in SAP Solution Manager

The first rule will create an Incident in SAP Solution Manager. To do so, create a rule with the following details in the “After Applying Changes” section of the Normal Incident workflow.

Description:

Create an Incident in SAP Solution Manager when the ticket is assigned to an Expert Group where the group is associated with an external system.

Condition:

${(entity.PhaseId =='InitialSupport' || entity.PhaseId =='Escalate') && entity.CurrentAssignment=='ExpertGroup' && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId=='<External System ID>' && entity.ExternalProcessReference == null && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.AuthorizedUser != entity.LastUpdatedByPerson && current_update.Output_c.IsChanged==false}

Meaning:

If the Incident is in phase Initial Support or Escalate and the current assignment is an Expert Group and the Expert Group is linked with the SAP SOLMAN via OO External System and the External Reference ID is still empty and the record isn't updated by the SAP Solution Manager Integration user, then create the Incident in SAP.

Settings:

Parameter Value Comment
Agent <your agent> See Step 1
Endpoint <your OO REST endpoint> See Step 2
Credentials <your credentials> See Step 2 - The same credentials as configured in the endpoint
HTTP Method POST
Uri Suffix /executions The URL to run OO flows via REST calls
Payload type JSON
Body ${concat('{"flowUuid":"<FlowID>", "runName": "SMAX to SAP Solution Manager Create - Incident ID: ',entity.Id,'", "logLevel": "STANDARD", "inputs":{"ExternalSystem": "',entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId,'","TenantID": "<TenantID>","SMAXIncidentID": "',entity.Id,'", "Title": "',substring(substitute(entity.DisplayLabel,'"','\"'),0,min(39, length(entity.DisplayLabel))),'", "Description": "',substitute(entity.Description,'"','\"'),'", "Priority": "',entity.Priority,'"}}')} The payload to send to OO to start the flow and passing the required input parameters.

Required parameters:

FlowID > the OO flow id in your env to create the Incidents in SAP

TenantID > The tenantID of your SMAX tenant.
Headers Accept: application/json

Content-type: application/json

 The required headers for the OO flow execution.
Result Select the “Output” field Select the “Output” field created in Step 5, section “Attributes”.

Example:

2 – Update Incident in SAP Solution Manager

The second rule will update the Incident in SAP Solution Manager when a new discussion for the External Service Desk was entered. The update details are added to the SAP ticket history to keep the SAP agent informed.

To do so, create a rule with the following details in the “After Applying Changes” section of the Normal Incident workflow.

Description:

Send comment of type "External Service Desk" to SAP Solution Manager, if the ticket is linked with an External Reference Number and assigned to an Expert Group and where the group is associated with an external system and where the solution isn't coming from the SAP system.

Condition:

${entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId=='<External System ID>' && entity.ExternalProcessReference != null && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.AuthorizedUser != entity.LastUpdatedByPerson && current_update.Output_c.IsChanged==false && count(comments_filtered(comments_added(current_update.Comments.OldValue, current_update.Comments.NewValue), 'CommentTo', 'ExternalServiceDesk')) > 0}

Meaning:

If the Incident is linked with an Expert Group and the Expert Group is linked with the External System and the External Reference ID isn't empty and the record isn't updated by the SAP Solution Manager Integration user, and a comment of type “External Service Desk” is entered, then send this comment to SAP Solution Manager.

Settings:

Parameter Value Comment
Agent <your agent> See Step 1
Endpoint <your OO REST endpoint> See Step 2
Credentials <your credentials> See Step 2 - The same credentials as configured in the endpoint
HTTP Method POST
Uri Suffix /executions The URL to run OO flows via REST calls
Payload type JSON
Body ${concat('{"flowUuid":"<FlowID>", "runName": "SMAX to SAP Solution Manager Update - Incident ID: ',entity.Id,'", "logLevel": "STANDARD", "inputs":{"ExternalSystem": "',entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId,'","TenantID": "<TenantID>","SMAXIncidentID": "',entity.Id,'", "SAPGUIID": "',entity.SAPGUIID_c,'", "SAPObjectID": "',entity.ExternalProcessReference,'", "Comments": "',substitute(concat(comments_filtered(comments_added(current_update.Comments.OldValue, current_update.Comments.NewValue), 'CommentTo', 'ExternalServiceDesk')),'"','\"'),'", "Event": "Update"}}')} The payload to send to OO to start the flow and passing the required input parameters.

Required parameters:

FlowID > the OO flow id in your env to create the Incidents in SAP

TenantID > The tenantID of your SMAX tenant.
Headers Accept: application/json

Content-type: application/json

 The required headers for the OO flow execution.
Result Select the “Output” field Select the “Output” field created in Step 5, section “Attributes”.

Example:

3 – Send solution details to SAP Solution Manager

The third rule will send an update with the solution details of the SMAX Incident to SAP Solution Manager. The solution details are added to the SAP ticket history to keep the SAP agent informed.

To do so, create a rule with the following details in the “After Applying Changes” section of the Normal Incident workflow.

Description:

Send a solution update to SAP Solution Manager if the ticket is resolved but still assigned to an Expert Group and where the group is associated with an external system and where the solution isn't coming from the SAP system.

Condition:

${current_update.PhaseId.IsChanged && current_update.PhaseId.NewValue == 'Validate' && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId=='<External System ID>' && entity.ExternalProcessReference != null && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.AuthorizedUser != entity.LastUpdatedByPerson && current_update.Output_c.IsChanged==false}}

Meaning:

If the Incident is moved to the Review phase (internal Name “Validate”) and the Incident is linked with an Expert Group and the Expert Group is linked with the an External System and the External Reference ID isn't empty and the record isn't updated by the SAP Solution Manager Integration user.

Settings:

Parameter Value Comment
Agent <your agent> See Step 1
Endpoint <your OO REST endpoint> See Step 2
Credentials <your credentials> See Step 2 - The same credentials as configured in the end point
HTTP Method POST
Uri Suffix /executions The URL to run OO flows via REST calls
Payload type JSON
Body ${concat('{"flowUuid":"<FlowID>", "runName": "SMAX to SAP Solution Manager Resolve - Incident ID: ',entity.Id,'", "logLevel": "STANDARD", "inputs":{"ExternalSystem": "',entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId,'","TenantID": "<TenantID>","SMAXIncidentID": "',entity.Id,'", "SAPGUIID": "',entity.SAPGUIID_c,'", "SAPObjectID": "',entity.ExternalProcessReference,'", "Solution": "',entity.Solution,'", "Event": "Resolve"}}')} The payload to send to OO to start the flow and passing the required input parameters.

Required parameters:

FlowID > the OO flow id in your env to create the Incidents in SAP

TenantID > The tenantID of your SMAX tenant.
Headers Accept: application/json

Content-type: application/json

 The required headers for the OO flow execution.
Result Select the “Output” field Select the “Output” field created in Step 5, section “Attributes”.

4 – Send closure information to SAP Solution Manager

The fourth rule will send an update with closure information of the SMAX Incident to SAP Solution Manager. The closure information is added to the SAP ticket history to keep the SAP agent informed.

To do so, create a rule with the following details in the “After Applying Changes” section of the Normal Incident workflow.

Description:

Send a closure update to SAP Solution Manager, if the ticket is closed and still assigned to an Expert Group and where the group is associated with an external system.

Condition:

${current_update.PhaseId.IsChanged && current_update.PhaseId.NewValue == 'Close' && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId=='<External System ID>' && entity.ExternalProcessReference != null && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.AuthorizedUser != entity.LastUpdatedByPerson && current_update.Output_c.IsChanged==false}

Meaning:

If the Incident is moved to the Closure phase (internal Name “Close”) and the Incident is linked with an Expert Group and the Expert Group is linked with the External System and the External Reference ID isn't empty and the record isn't updated by the SAP Solution Manager Integration user.

Endpoint <your OO REST endpoint> See Step 2

5 – Pull updates from SMAX via Custom Action (Button Click)

The fifth rule will trigger an OO flow to pull the latest SAP updates into Service Management.

To do so, create a rule with the following details in the “After Applying Changes” section of the Normal Incident workflow.

Description:

This rule will pull the latest updates from SAP Solution Manager.

Condition:

${current_update.CustomActionCount_c.IsChanged && entity.CustomActionName_c=='GetUpdatesFromSAP' && entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId=='<External System ID>' && entity.ExternalProcessReference != null}

Meaning:

If the custom action Get Updates from SAP is clicked and the Expert Group is linked with an External System and External Reference ID isn't empty, then a job to pull the data is started.

Settings:

Parameter Value Comment
Agent <your agent> See Step 1
Endpoint <your OO REST endpoint> See Step 2
Credentials <your credentials> See Step 2 - The same credentials as configured in the endpoint
HTTP Method POST
Uri Suffix /executions The URL to run OO flows via REST calls
Payload type JSON
Body ${concat('{"flowUuid":"<FlowID>", "runName": "SMAX to SAP Solution Manager Get Data - Incident ID: ',entity.Id,'", "logLevel": "STANDARD", "inputs":{"ExternalSystem": "',entity.ExpertGroup.BelongsToExternalSystem.SystemId,'","TenantID": "<TenantID>","SMAXIncidentID": "',entity.Id,'", "SMAXLastPull": "',entity.LastPull_c,'", "SAPGUIID": "',entity.SAPGUIID_c,'", "SAPObjectID": "',entity.ExternalProcessReference,'"}}')} The payload to send to OO to start the flow and passing the required input parameters.

Required parameters:

FlowID > the OO flow id in your env to create the Incidents in SAP

TenantID > The tenantID of your SMAX tenant.

6 – Pull updates from SMAX via scheduler

This rule will trigger an OO flow to pull the latest SAP updates into SMAX based on a scheduler.

To do so, create a rule in the “Per Schedule” section of the Normal Incident workflow. Select Fixed time schedule and Set multiple fields to create the rule.

Description:

This rule schedules a pull to get the latest updates from SAP Solution Manager

Condition: none

Meaning:

If the record isn't closed and the Expert Group is linked with an external system and the External Reference fields isn't empty.

Settings:

Parameter Value Comment
Initial Timeout 1 The rule start the first time after one hour
Initial Timeout Unit hour

Verify the integration

Either follow the demo steps at the beginning of this document or follow the steps below.

  1. Create a new Incident and categorize the Incident.
  2. Set the Incident assignment to “Expert Group", and select the assignment group linked with the SAP system. In this example, the group name in SAP Support (Europe).
  3. Go to the Integration > Endpoint section of Service Management,and check whether a REST event has been created. The following figure shows an example.
  4. If the REST event was not created, check the conditions of your business rules.
  5. Go to the Operations Orchestration Web UI, and navigate to Run Management > Run Explorer and check the status of your OO flows.  
  6. If the OO flow failed, click the flow and look into the step details.

Limitations 

This integration has the following limitations. 

ID  Comment 
1  In rich text fields, the following elements aren't supported:  
  • Special characters like “, }, {, ‘, [, ] 
  • Colored, bold, underlined text 
  • Embedded pictures in Rich Text fields 
2  Attachments aren't transferred.  
3  When creating Incidents in SAP via service AI_CRM_GW_CREATE_INCIDENT_SRV, tickets can't be assigned to a group in SAP via this interface. This requires modifications in SAP. 
4  In this integration, SMAX doesn't store the SMAX ticket id in an attribute in the SAP database. This requires modifications in SAP.
